wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the farruh-folio-wave project. Explain its purpose as a modern, interactive personal portfolio website built with React and TypeScript. Describe the architectural goals of being responsive, visually engaging, and performance-optimized. Highlight key features such as parallax effects, animated particles, smooth scrolling navigation, and data-driven content rendering from JSON files. Document how components are organized into logical directories (effects, layout, pages, ui), and explain the role of core files like App.tsx in orchestrating routing and global providers (QueryClient, TooltipProvider, Toaster). Include practical examples from the actual implementation, such as the use of React Query for data handling and Vite for fast development. Address integration points like contact form mailto links and potential CMS replacement of JSON files. Provide context for beginners on what the application does and why certain technologies were chosen, while giving experienced developers insight into the high-level design decisions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Layout Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the layout components in farruh-folio-wave, focusing on Navigation.tsx as the primary structural element. Explain its role in managing scroll-spy detection, active section highlighting, and smooth scrolling between sections. Document how it integrates with the overall page structure via Index.tsx and responds to user interactions such as clicks and scroll events. Describe the responsive behavior using use-mobile.ts hook for mobile hamburger menu toggling. Include code examples showing navigation state management, anchor linking, and integration with parallax effects. Address accessibility considerations including keyboard navigation and ARIA attributes. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like incorrect active states or broken scroll targeting.

wiki_catalogs.name: Parallax Background
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the ParallaxBackground component in farruh-folio-wave. Explain its implementation using React's useEffect and requestAnimationFrame for smooth animation, leveraging the useParallax hook to track scroll and mouse position with throttling via rafThrottle. Detail how transform: translate3d is used with GPU acceleration for high-performance layer movement across multiple visual elements (particles, large shapes, grid). Document all configuration options from ParallaxConfig.ts including preset types (minimal, standard, intense, elegant, performance), their impact on particle count, opacity, blur intensity, and responsiveness. Describe the lerp (linear interpolation) system that ensures fluid motion by smoothing rapid input changes. Provide concrete examples from Index.tsx showing how this effect wraps the entire portfolio layout. Include usage of CSS Modules for scoped styling and Tailwind’s blur utilities. Address performance considerations such as limiting particle count on mobile devices, disabling effects conditionally via use-mobile.tsx, and optimizing re-renders through useMemo and useCallback. For beginners, explain parallax design principles; for experts, dive into throttling strategies, DOM resize handling, and memory management via cleanup in useEffect.

wiki_catalogs.name: Parallax Background
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the ParallaxBackground component implementation. Explain how it creates a multi-layered depth effect using mouse movement and scroll position data through requestAnimationFrame throttling and smooth interpolation (lerp). Document the configuration interface (ParallaxConfig) with all available properties including particle settings, shape opacity, movement intensity, animation smoothness, and visual effects like blur and grid size. Illustrate how default values are merged with user-provided configurations and clamped for safety. Describe the rendering layers: static gradient background, floating geometric shapes with transform3d translations, gradient overlay with radial gradients following the mouse, and grid pattern overlay. Detail performance optimizations such as rafThrottle, CSS will-change hints via translate3d, GPU acceleration, and dynamic grid cell calculation based on viewport. Provide practical examples of customizing the effect intensity, adjusting parallax speed, and modifying shape sizes. Include debugging guidance for janky animations, cross-browser inconsistencies, and memory leaks from event listeners. Address integration with useParallax hook and consumption by parent components.

wiki_catalogs.name: Hero Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the Hero section component. Describe its visual layout, including the badge, name, subtitle, description, stats display, and call-to-action buttons. Explain how it fetches data from hero.json using useEffect and async/await, maps color palettes to stats dynamically, and handles smooth scrolling to the About and Contact sections via scrollToAbout() and scrollToContact(). Document the use of useParallax hook for floating background elements with subtle motion effects. Include code examples showing JSON structure expectations, prop usage, and integration with global navigation. Address accessibility considerations such as button labeling and keyboard navigation. Provide customization guidance for modifying colors, text content, and button behaviors. For advanced users, discuss performance implications of parallax rendering and potential memoization strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Form Controls
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for all form control components in the shadcn/ui library used in the portfolio. Explain the implementation of accessible form elements including inputs, textareas, checkboxes, radio groups, selects, switches, and OTP inputs. Detail how form.tsx integrates with react-hook-form for validation, error handling, and state management. Provide usage examples showing proper composition of form fields with labels, error messages, and accessibility attributes. Document styling through Tailwind CSS and support for dark mode. Include best practices for building user-friendly forms, performance considerations when handling large forms, and troubleshooting common issues such as uncontrolled state or missing validation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Hero Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Hero section component. Explain its implementation using React and TypeScript, including how it fetches data from hero.json via the Fetch API and renders dynamic content with CSS Modules. Document the use of the useParallax hook for creating subtle visual effects through mouse and scroll interactions. Detail the structure of the JSON schema, including fields like badge, name, subtitle, description, buttons, and stats. Describe the color palette system that dynamically assigns colors to stat elements. Explain the smooth scrolling functionality to navigate between sections (About and Contact). Provide examples of how to customize the component by modifying the JSON data or extending TypeScript interfaces while maintaining type safety. Address common issues such as failed data loading and responsive layout behavior on mobile devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack & Dependencies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack used in farruh-folio-wave. Detail each framework and library including React 18 for component architecture, TypeScript for type safety, Tailwind CSS for utility-first styling, and Vite as the build tool. Explain the role of @tanstack/react-query in managing data fetching and caching, shadcn/ui components built on Radix UI for accessible UI elements, and lucide-react for scalable icons. Cover development tools like ESLint, PostCSS, and Autoprefixer. Include version information pulled from package.json and describe configuration specifics in vite.config.ts (plugins, server settings), tailwind.config.ts (themes, plugins), and tsconfig.json (module resolution, strict typing). Provide practical examples showing how these technologies integrate—such as using Vite's HMR during development or Tailwind's JIT mode for rapid styling. For beginners, explain what each tool does at a high level; for experts, detail optimization techniques and custom configurations. Address common issues like dependency conflicts and provide troubleshooting tips for setup problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Visual Effects Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the visual effects system, detailing ParallaxBackground.tsx implementation that enables multi-layered depth effects based on mouse movement and scroll position. Explain how ParallaxConfig.ts defines preset configurations (minimal, standard, intense, elegant, performance) and how they are consumed by the component. Document AnimatedParticles.tsx for dynamic particle animations and FloatingWords.tsx for typographic motion effects. Illustrate data flow from configuration → useParallax hook → CSS transforms. Include performance optimization strategies such as requestAnimationFrame throttling, will-change usage, and GPU acceleration. Provide practical examples of customizing effect intensity and responsiveness. Address debugging techniques for janky animations and cross-browser rendering inconsistencies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Animated Particles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AnimatedParticles component in farruh-folio-wave. Explain its canvas-based rendering approach using HTML5 Canvas API for high-performance particle systems. Detail how particles are created with randomized properties (position, velocity, size, color, opacity) based on configuration props like particleCount, speedRange, and colors array. Describe the animation loop powered by requestAnimationFrame with configurable FPS throttling to balance visual quality and performance. Explain edge-bounce logic that keeps particles within viewport bounds and connection-drawing algorithm that renders subtle lines between nearby particles under maxConnectionDistance. Document integration with CSS Modules for canvas styling and responsive resizing using devicePixelRatio for sharp rendering on high-DPI screens. Provide practical examples of how this effect enhances background depth in the portfolio. Address performance implications of high particle counts and suggest optimization strategies such as lowering fps or disabling on mobile. Include guidance on customizing color schemes to match brand identity and adjusting density for different devices. For beginners, introduce basic canvas concepts; for experts, analyze memory efficiency, double buffering avoidance, and WebGL potential upgrades.

wiki_catalogs.name: Animated Particles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AnimatedParticles component that renders dynamic particle systems on a canvas. Explain the particle physics simulation including velocity vectors, boundary bouncing, and connection lines between nearby particles. Document the ParticlesConfig interface with configurable properties: particleCount, colors array in rgba format, maxConnectionDistance for link visibility, speedRange, sizeRange, opacityRange, and fps for performance control. Describe the animation loop using requestAnimationFrame with delta-time-based frame limiting to maintain consistent speed across devices. Illustrate how devicePixelRatio is handled for sharp rendering on high-DPI screens and how canvas resizing works responsively. Detail performance considerations including particle count impact on FPS, optimized connection drawing (only forward pairs), and context scaling. Provide usage examples showing how to customize color themes, reduce CPU/GPU load via lower particle counts or FPS, and disable connections for minimal effects. Include troubleshooting tips for canvas rendering issues, memory bloat, and flickering on low-end devices. Explain integration patterns with other visual effects and accessibility implications of animated backgrounds.

wiki_catalogs.name: About Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the About section. Detail its two-column layout featuring a personal profile card on the left and professional information cards on the right. Explain how it loads structured data from about.json including personalInfo, interests, bio paragraphs with [[text|color]] markup syntax, achievements, and statistics. Document the dynamic icon resolution system that maps string-based icon names from JSON to Lucide React components via iconsMap. Describe the color palette assignment logic for contact cards and how CSS variables (--card-gradient, --text-color, etc.) enable dynamic theming. Illustrate the parseHighlight function's role in rendering colored text spans within bio content. Provide usage examples for adding new personal info entries or interest items. Include accessibility notes on semantic HTML structure and screen reader compatibility. Offer troubleshooting tips for common issues like missing icons or broken links.

wiki_catalogs.name: Overlays and Modals
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for overlay and modal components including Dialog, Sheet, Popover, AlertDialog, and Toast notifications. Describe their role in user interaction, accessibility compliance (ARIA roles, focus trapping), and responsive behavior across devices. Explain the implementation of Sonner-based toast system with useToast hook for programmatic notification triggering. Document how these components handle z-index stacking, backdrop interactions, and keyboard navigation. Provide practical examples from the codebase showing contact form success messages (toast) and confirmation dialogs. Include guidance on theming, animation customization via CSS, and performance optimization when rendering dynamic overlays.

wiki_catalogs.name: About Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the About section component. Explain its architecture in React with TypeScript, focusing on data fetching from about.json and rendering structured personal information, bio, interests, achievements, and statistics. Document the dynamic icon mapping system that translates string-based icon names from JSON into Lucide React components. Describe the color palette assignment logic used for contact cards and how CSS variables are applied for gradient backgrounds and hover effects. Detail the parseHighlight utility function that enables rich text formatting with [[text|color]] syntax in the bio. Explain the responsive grid layout separating profile and professional info. Cover error handling during data fetch and loading states. Provide guidance on extending the component with new personal info fields or customizing interest icons while preserving type integrity. Include troubleshooting tips for common rendering issues and performance optimization considerations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for setting up and running the farruh-folio-wave project locally. Provide step-by-step installation instructions starting from cloning the repository to launching the development server. Include prerequisites (Node.js v18+, npm/yarn), exact commands (`npm install`, `npm run dev`), and expected output. Explain how to build for production using `npm run build` and where output is placed (`dist/`). Reference index.html as the entry point and vite.config.ts for development server configuration. Include environment-specific considerations such as port assignment and HTTPS setup. Offer guidance on verifying successful installation through browser access (http://localhost:5173). For beginners, clarify terms like 'development server' and 'build process'; for advanced users, include options for customizing Vite behavior via command-line flags. Incorporate real code snippets from package.json scripts and highlight critical files involved in setup. Address common pitfalls like missing dependencies or incorrect Node versions and their solutions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Page Section Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for all page-level components that represent distinct sections of the portfolio: Hero, About, Experience, Projects, Skills, Strengths, Education, and Contact. Explain their uniform pattern of loading JSON data from /public/data/*.json files using fetch or React Query, and rendering structured content with consistent styling via CSS Modules. Document shared architectural patterns including data-fetching lifecycle, error handling, loading states, and responsive layouts. Highlight unique behaviors per component—such as project filtering or contact form submission logic. Show integration points with global navigation and scroll-spy tracking. Provide examples of extending these components with new fields or modifying existing ones while maintaining type safety through TypeScript interfaces.

wiki_catalogs.name: Floating Words
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the FloatingWords component in farruh-folio-wave. Explain its purpose in displaying dynamic, animated tech keywords that enhance personal branding and technical identity. Detail how it uses React refs to directly manipulate DOM elements for performant transform animations via translate3d and rotate. Describe the physics-inspired movement model where each word has velocity (vx, vy) and optional rotation (vr), updated in a requestAnimationFrame loop using delta time (dt) for frame-rate independence. Explain configurable placement logic that prioritizes side areas (left/right) over center based on sideOnlyPercentage, enhancing readability. Document customization options including speed, rotationSpeed, opacity, fontSize, and bounce behavior. Show how gradients from CSS Modules are randomly assigned for visual variety. Provide real-world usage context from the portfolio where these words float over background layers to emphasize skills without obstructing content. Address accessibility concerns (e.g., motion preferences via prefers-reduced-motion) and performance tips like reducing count on low-end devices. For beginners, clarify animation timing concepts; for experts, discuss ref array management, avoiding layout thrashing, and potential Web Workers offloading.

wiki_catalogs.name: Floating Words
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the FloatingWords component that displays animated tech keywords with floating and rotating motion. Explain the physics-based animation system using velocity vectors (vx/vy) and rotation velocity (vr) updated via requestAnimationFrame with delta time (dt) for frame-rate independence. Document all props: count, speed, rotationSpeed, opacity, fontSize, placement percentages (sideOnlyPercentage, centerAreaStart/end, leftSideEnd, rightSideStart), and boolean flags for enableRotation and enableBounce. Describe the word generation process selecting randomly from a predefined techWords array and assigning random gradients from six CSS classes. Illustrate how positionsRef tracks real-time coordinates and angles for each word, enabling DOM updates via transform3d and rotate transforms. Detail two movement modes: bouncing within viewport bounds or wrapping around edges when enableBounce is false. Cover styling aspects including gradient backgrounds, font sizing, and opacity controls. Provide customization examples such as creating themed word lists, adjusting spatial distribution, disabling rotation for cleaner look, and optimizing for mobile performance. Include debugging guidance for layout shifts, text clipping, and animation stuttering.

wiki_catalogs.name: Experience Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the Experience section. Explain its timeline-based layout with vertical connector lines and animated experience cards. Describe how it fetches an array of job experiences from experience.json and renders each with company, title, dates, duration, type, location, achievements, and technologies. Document the color-coded design system where each experience has a designated color applied to icons, badges, timeline dots, and decorative elements. Detail the animation sequence controlled by CSS classes and inline animationDelay styles. Explain the structure of achievement lists and technology badges displayed within collapsible sections. Provide examples of valid JSON schema for new experience entries. Discuss responsive behavior across device sizes and offer customization options for changing timeline styling or adding new metadata fields.

wiki_catalogs.name: Navigation Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the navigation component suite that supports both global and contextual navigation in the portfolio. Cover NavigationMenu for top-level site sections, Tabs for content organization within pages, DropdownMenu and Menubar for hierarchical actions, Command palette-style search interface, and Sidebar for layout structuring. Explain keyboard accessibility, screen reader support, and responsive adaptations (e.g., mobile menu collapsing). Detail integration with the main Navigation.tsx component and scroll-spy functionality. Provide usage patterns for composing nested navigation structures, styling with Tailwind, and ensuring consistent UX across breakpoints. Address common pitfalls like event propagation issues and focus management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Experience Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Experience section component. Explain its implementation using React and TypeScript to render a timeline of professional roles fetched from experience.json. Document the data model including company, title, dates, duration, location, achievements, technologies, and color-coded themes. Describe the animated timeline UI with colored dots, gradient overlays, and staggered entry animations based on index. Explain how CSS Modules and dynamic class naming enable theme consistency across job entries. Detail the structure of achievement lists and technology badges with category-specific styling. Cover integration with global navigation via the 'experience' ID anchor. Provide examples of adding new experience entries through JSON updates and extending the TypeScript interface for additional metadata. Address accessibility considerations for screen readers and responsiveness on smaller screens.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the component-based structure of farruh-folio-wave. Describe the high-level design principles including separation of concerns, reusability, and composability. Break down the component hierarchy starting from App.tsx (root provider wrapper) to Index.tsx (main page composer), then to individual section components (Hero, About, Projects, etc.) and shared UI elements. Explain architectural patterns used: CSS Modules for scoped styling, custom hooks (useParallax, use-mobile) for logic reuse, and configuration-driven effects via ParallaxConfig.ts. Illustrate data flow from JSON files → React components via inline fetch or React Query, and user interaction flow via events and state updates. Use diagrams to show parent-child relationships and integration between visual effects (ParallaxBackground) and navigation (Navigation.tsx). Discuss trade-offs such as client-side data loading vs API integration and performance implications of animation-heavy designs. Address scalability considerations and boundaries between presentation and logic layers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Shared UI Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the TiltCard.tsx component designed for interactive card elements that respond to mouse movement with 3D tilt effects. Explain its implementation using CSS transforms and JavaScript event listeners to track pointer position relative to the card. Describe how it enhances user engagement through subtle motion feedback and is used across various sections like Projects or Skills. Detail props interface, customization options (e.g., tilt angle, scale), and performance optimizations like passive event listeners and transform-origin control. Provide usage examples within different contexts and demonstrate integration with other UI components. Address accessibility concerns and fallback behaviors when JavaScript is disabled or on touch devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Projects Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the Projects section implementation thoroughly. Describe its grid layout of interactive TiltCard components that respond to mouse movement with 3D transforms. Explain how project data is loaded from projects.json and enriched with dynamic color palettes during mapping. Detail the integration with TiltCard.tsx for immersive hover effects and the application of CSS gradient backgrounds via custom properties (--card-gradient, --border-hover). Cover all content areas: project title, category badge, role, description, impact statement, challenges, key features (highlights), technologies stack, and external links (GitHub/Demo). Document conditional rendering logic for hideCode/hideDemo flags and disabled link states. Provide code snippets demonstrating how to add new projects with proper JSON formatting. Include accessibility recommendations for keyboard navigation within tilt cards and performance considerations for GPU-accelerated animations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Display Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for data display components used to present structured information in the portfolio. Explain Card for grouping related content, Table for tabular data (e.g., experience entries), Accordion for collapsible content sections, Carousel for project galleries, Chart for visualizing skill levels, and ScrollArea for overflow management. Document their composition patterns, responsive behaviors, and integration with JSON-driven content. Include examples from Projects and Experience sections showing real-world usage. Cover accessibility considerations (semantic HTML, ARIA), performance implications of virtualized content, and customization options via props and Tailwind classes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Projects Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Projects section component. Explain its composition using React and TypeScript, rendering project cards from projects.json with dynamic color assignment via the TiltCard wrapper. Document the data schema including title, description, technologies, impact, challenges, highlights, and optional GitHub/demo links. Describe the integration with the shared TiltCard component for interactive 3D tilt effects and how CSS variables control gradient backgrounds and hover states. Explain conditional rendering logic for hiding code or demo links when URLs are missing. Detail the responsive grid layout and section organization including role, impact, challenges, and key features. Provide instructions for adding new projects, customizing categories, or modifying the highlight rendering logic. Include best practices for maintaining performance with multiple animated cards and ensuring accessibility compliance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Visual Effects System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the visual effects system in farruh-folio-wave. Focus on the implementation of parallax background effects that respond to mouse movement and scroll position using the useParallax hook and configurable presets defined in ParallaxConfig.ts. Detail how AnimatedParticles creates dynamic particle animations and FloatingWords enables floating text elements. Explain the technical mechanics behind transform and translate3d CSS properties driven by React state and requestAnimationFrame for smooth performance. Document public interfaces including props accepted by each effect component, configuration options (minimal, standard, intense, elegant, performance), and performance considerations like GPU acceleration and frame rate optimization. Provide concrete usage examples from the codebase showing how these effects wrap main content in Index.tsx. For beginners, explain basic animation concepts; for experts, dive into interpolation algorithms and throttling strategies. Address common issues like jank on low-end devices and solutions such as reducing layer count or disabling effects on mobile.

wiki_catalogs.name: UI Library Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the shadcn/ui-based component library used throughout the application. Cover each primitive including buttons, cards, forms, inputs, dialogs, sheets, navigation menus, and alerts. Explain their role in ensuring design consistency, accessibility compliance (WCAG), and responsiveness. Document how they are extended with Tailwind CSS classes and composed into higher-order components. Detail form handling with react-hook-form integration via form.tsx and state management for interactive elements like tabs and accordions. Include usage guidelines, theming capabilities through CSS variables, and dark mode support. Provide migration tips when upgrading shadcn/ui versions and best practices for avoiding style conflicts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Skills Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Skills section. Describe its modular grid layout of category cards, each representing a technical domain such as programming languages, databases, or cloud platforms. Explain how it fetches categorized skill data from skills.json containing icon identifiers, titles, and skill arrays. Document the dynamic icon resolution mechanism that converts string-based icon names into Lucide React components using the iconsMap object. Detail the per-category color assignment logic using predefined colorPalettes and the application of CSS variables for gradient backgrounds and text colors. Illustrate the hierarchical structure: category header with icon and title, followed by a list of individual skills with dot indicators. Provide examples of extending the JSON schema with new categories or skills. Address responsive design behavior and offer customization guidance for adjusting spacing, typography, or animation delays.

wiki_catalogs.name: Feedback and Status Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create thorough documentation for UI elements that communicate status, hierarchy, and loading states. Cover Alert for important messages, Badge for metadata tagging (e.g., tech stack labels), Separator for visual grouping, Skeleton for loading placeholders, Progress indicators, and HoverCard for contextual tooltips. Explain their role in enhancing user experience by providing immediate visual feedback. Detail implementation using Tailwind CSS and seamless integration with other components. Use examples such as skeleton loaders during data fetch and badges in project tags. Include accessibility guidelines, theming options, and performance benefits of using Skeleton for perceived speed improvement.

wiki_catalogs.name: Skills Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Skills section component. Explain its implementation in React with TypeScript, loading categorized technical skills from skills.json and rendering them in a visually consistent grid. Document the data structure with icon identifiers, category titles, and skill arrays. Describe the icon mapping mechanism that resolves string-based icon names to Lucide React components. Explain the dynamic color palette system that assigns unique gradients to each category card using CSS variables. Detail the UI elements including category headers with icons, skill item dots, and shimmer effects for visual polish. Cover animation delays for staggered card appearance and responsive layout behavior. Provide guidance on extending the component with new skill categories, updating icons, or modifying the styling system while preserving type safety. Address potential issues with icon resolution fallbacks and performance implications of multiple animated elements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Navigation System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the navigation system in farruh-folio-wave. Describe both desktop and mobile implementations, focusing on Navigation.tsx which uses shadcn/ui's navigation-menu for structured menus and implements hamburger toggle functionality via use-mobile.tsx. Explain scroll-spy detection that highlights active sections based on viewport position and smooth scrolling behavior triggered by anchor links. Document event handling for click interactions, state management for mobile menu visibility, and responsive breakpoints that switch between desktop and mobile layouts. Include usage patterns showing how navigation items link to hash routes (#about, #projects) and coordinate with page sections. Provide code examples demonstrating prop usage and customization options. Address accessibility compliance including keyboard navigation and ARIA attributes. For beginners, clarify concepts like 'scroll-spy' and 'smooth scrolling'; for advanced users, discuss optimization techniques like debouncing scroll events and intersection observer tuning. Cover common bugs such as incorrect active states and their debugging approaches.

wiki_catalogs.name: Strengths Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the Strengths section. Explain its purpose in showcasing soft skills, core competencies, or professional values through visually engaging cards. Describe how it retrieves strength data from strengths.json, which includes attributes like title, description, proficiency level, and visual theme. Document the rendering logic that maps each strength to a stylized card with progress indicators, thematic icons, and descriptive text. Cover any interactive elements such as hover effects, expandable details, or filtering capabilities if present. Detail the styling approach using Tailwind CSS and CSS Modules for consistent theming. Provide implementation examples for adding new strengths or modifying existing ones. Include best practices for writing effective strength descriptions and aligning them with career branding goals.

wiki_catalogs.name: Strengths Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Strengths section component. Explain its React and TypeScript implementation for displaying core competencies loaded from strengths.json. Document the expected JSON structure containing strength labels, descriptions, and visual properties. Describe the rendering pattern using CSS Modules for consistent styling and potential integration with parallax or animation effects. Explain how the component fits within the overall portfolio narrative and complements other sections like Skills and Experience. Detail any interactive behaviors such as hover effects or click-to-expand details if implemented. Provide instructions for updating strength values, adding new attributes, or customizing the visual presentation. Include recommendations for aligning strength descriptions with professional branding and ensuring mobile responsiveness.

wiki_catalogs.name: Content Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the content management system in farruh-folio-wave. Detail the JSON schema definitions used across public/data/*.json files, including field types, required properties, and structural conventions for hero, about, experience, projects, skills, strengths, and education sections. Explain how data flows from static JSON assets into React components via fetch or React Query, and how it's rendered dynamically within respective page components. Document naming consistency, localization readiness, and extensibility patterns for adding new fields or sections. Include sample data structures and illustrate entity relationships (e.g., projects containing title, description, tags, image). Address data validation practices, error handling for missing/malformed JSON, and caching strategies via React Query. Provide guidelines for contributors updating content without touching code. For beginners, explain JSON basics and file linking; for experts, discuss potential migration paths to headless CMS or API backends. Cover performance impacts of client-side data loading and mitigation strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Education Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create thorough documentation for the Education section. Detail its chronological presentation of academic credentials, certifications, or training programs loaded from education.json. Explain the data model including fields such as institution, degree, dates, location, honors, and relevant coursework. Describe the visual design pattern—likely similar to the Experience section but focused on academic milestones—with appropriate icons, timelines, and card-based layouts. Document any special features like credential verification links, digital badges, or accreditation information. Illustrate how CSS modules and Tailwind utilities create cohesive styling aligned with the overall portfolio aesthetic. Provide guidance for international degree equivalencies or multilingual transcripts if supported. Offer customization options for displaying GPA, honors, or extracurricular activities.

wiki_catalogs.name: Education Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Education section component. Explain its implementation using React and TypeScript to render academic history from education.json. Document the data model including institution, degree, dates, honors, and relevant coursework or achievements. Describe the UI layout, potentially featuring a timeline or card-based design similar to the Experience section. Explain styling approaches using CSS Modules and integration with global design tokens. Detail any interactive elements such as expandable details or certification badges. Cover accessibility considerations for chronological information and screen reader navigation. Provide clear instructions for adding new educational entries, modifying date formats, or extending the schema with GPA or thesis information. Address alignment with resume standards and internationalization needs for different credential systems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Section Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for each section component in the portfolio. Describe the visual appearance, layout structure, and content rendering logic of Hero, About, Experience, Projects, Skills, Strengths, Education, and Contact sections. Document how each component imports and displays data from corresponding JSON files in /public/data, handles conditional rendering, and applies consistent styling via Tailwind classes and CSS Modules. Explain unique behaviors such as form handling in Contact.tsx, list rendering in Projects and Experience, and skill categorization in Skills.tsx. Include usage examples with code snippets showing component composition and prop drilling patterns. Provide accessibility guidelines, responsive design adaptations, and animation integrations (e.g., fade-ins on scroll). For beginners, walk through reading data from JSON and mapping it to JSX; for experts, analyze rendering performance and memoization opportunities. Address common customization needs like adding new project entries or modifying section order.

wiki_catalogs.name: Contact Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the Contact section comprehensively. Explain its dual-mode communication interface combining a direct contact form and clickable external links (email, social media, professional networks). Describe how contact configuration is sourced from contact.json, defining available methods, labels, URLs, and form settings. Detail the form submission handling logic—if implemented—including state management, input validation, loading states, and success/error feedback. Cover accessibility features such as proper labeling, focus management, and ARIA attributes. Document the responsive adaptation between desktop and mobile layouts, especially regarding link density and tap targets. Provide instructions for integrating with third-party messaging services or backend APIs. Include security considerations for preventing spam and privacy guidelines for handling user-submitted information.

wiki_catalogs.name: Contact Section
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Contact section component. Explain its React and TypeScript implementation for displaying communication options sourced from contact.json. Document the data structure including email, social media links, messaging platforms, and form configuration flags. Describe the UI components such as clickable icons with external links, hover effects, and responsive layout patterns. Explain any conditional rendering logic based on JSON configuration (e.g., showing/hiding specific contact methods). Detail integration with the global navigation system via the 'contact' anchor ID. Provide guidance on securely managing contact information, preventing spam, and configuring deep links for applications like WhatsApp or Telegram. Include instructions for adding new contact methods, customizing icons, or integrating with third-party messaging services while maintaining consistent styling and accessibility standards.

wiki_catalogs.name: Styling Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the styling strategy in farruh-folio-wave. Explain the dual approach combining Tailwind CSS for utility-first rapid development and CSS Modules for component-scoped styles requiring complex selectors or animations. Detail how Tailwind classes are used throughout components for layout, spacing, colors, and responsiveness, referencing tailwind.config.ts for theme extensions and plugin usage. Describe how CSS Modules (e.g., Hero.module.css) encapsulate styles to prevent leakage and enable local class names. Cover advanced styling features like glass morphism (backdrop blur), gradient backgrounds, hover effects, and tilt card interactions via TiltCard.tsx. Include theming capabilities through Tailwind’s color palette and dark mode support. Provide practical examples showing class composition and responsive modifiers. For beginners, teach fundamental Tailwind syntax; for experts, discuss purging unused styles in production and optimizing bundle size. Address debugging style conflicts and ensuring cross-browser compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for state management patterns in farruh-folio-wave. Focus on React hooks such as useState, useEffect, and custom hooks like useParallax (tracking mouse/scroll position) and use-mobile (responsive breakpoint detection). Explain how state is managed within functional components for UI interactions including navigation toggles, form inputs, and toast notifications. Document the use of React Query for declarative data fetching and caching of JSON content. Cover form state handling in Contact.tsx using controlled components and validation logic. Include utility functions in utils.ts for className merging and other reusable logic. Provide code examples illustrating state flow from child to parent via callbacks and lifting state up when necessary. For beginners, explain React’s reactivity model; for experts, analyze performance implications of frequent re-renders and optimization with useMemo and useCallback. Address common issues like stale closures and unmounted component updates.

wiki_catalogs.name: Responsive Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the responsive design implementation in farruh-folio-wave. Describe the mobile-first approach using Tailwind’s breakpoint system (sm, md, lg, xl) defined in tailwind.config.ts. Explain how use-mobile.tsx detects device width and alters component behavior accordingly (e.g., switching navigation to hamburger menu). Detail adaptive layouts across different screen sizes, including font scaling, grid adjustments, and hiding/showing elements. Cover responsive interactions such as touch-friendly buttons, swipe gestures (if applicable), and optimized tap targets. Include testing guidelines using browser DevTools and real devices. Provide examples from Navigation.tsx (desktop vs mobile menu) and TiltCard.tsx (adjusted tilt sensitivity on mobile). For beginners, introduce media queries and fluid design concepts; for experts, discuss container queries (if used), viewport units, and performance tuning for mobile GPUs. Address common layout bugs and debugging workflows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Performance Optimization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content focused on performance optimization in farruh-folio-wave. Cover rendering performance improvements such as minimizing re-renders with React.memo, useCallback, and useMemo where appropriate. Discuss bundle size optimization via Vite’s tree-shaking, code splitting, and minification using esbuild. Detail asset optimization including image compression, lazy loading (if implemented), and efficient icon usage via lucide-react. Explain animation performance techniques like leveraging GPU-accelerated transforms (translate3d), requestAnimationFrame throttling in useParallax, and reducing repaints through will-change hints. Address JavaScript execution efficiency, avoiding expensive operations in render cycles. Include build-time optimizations from vite.config.ts (preloading, chunking) and Tailwind’s purge settings. Reference Lighthouse scores mentioned in README.md and strategies to maintain high performance metrics. For beginners, explain core web vitals; for experts, provide profiling methods using Chrome DevTools and optimization benchmarks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Customization Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for customizing farruh-folio-wave for personal use. Provide step-by-step instructions for updating personal information by modifying JSON files in /public/data (hero.json, about.json, etc.), replacing the resume PDF, and changing project details in Projects.tsx. Explain theme customization through tailwind.config.ts including color palette changes, font updates, and layout tweaks. Guide users on adding new sections by creating new components and JSON files, then integrating them into Index.tsx and Navigation.tsx. Cover branding updates such as favicon, meta tags in index.html, and social sharing images. Include best practices for maintaining code quality during modifications and avoiding breaking existing functionality. For beginners, offer safe edit zones and backup recommendations; for experts, suggest advanced customizations like integrating analytics, CMS backends, or internationalization. Reference the README.md’s customization section and expand with deeper technical insights.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for deploying farruh-folio-wave to production environments. Explain the build process using `npm run build` which generates static files in the dist/ directory via Vite’s production pipeline. Detail hosting options including Vercel, Netlify, GitHub Pages, and AWS S3, with specific deployment commands and configuration requirements for each. Cover security headers defined in public/_headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, etc.) and their importance for protecting against XSS and clickjacking. Include CI/CD integration examples using GitHub Actions or other platforms to automate builds and deployments. Address environment-specific configurations such as base URLs, asset paths, and cache invalidation strategies. Provide post-deployment verification steps and monitoring suggestions. For beginners, simplify deployment into drag-and-drop scenarios; for experts, discuss advanced topics like edge caching, CDN integration, and zero-downtime deployments. Reference the README.md’s deployment section and enhance with platform-specific nuances.

wiki_catalogs.name: Contribution Guidelines
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for contributing to farruh-folio-wave. Outline the intended contribution workflow including forking the repository, creating feature branches, making changes, and submitting pull requests. Document code style standards enforced by ESLint (referencing eslint.config.js) and formatting rules via Prettier if configured. Specify testing requirements—even though there are no explicit test files currently, recommend establishing unit and integration tests using Vitest or Jest. Explain issue reporting procedures: how to search existing issues, write clear bug reports with reproduction steps, and propose new features. Clarify licensing under MIT and attribution expectations. Encourage documentation updates alongside code changes. For beginners, provide a friendly onboarding path; for maintainers, suggest review processes and merge criteria. Reference the CONTRIBUTING section in README.md and expand with technical enforcement mechanisms like pre-commit hooks or GitHub Actions for linting.

wiki_catalogs.name: Troubleshooting
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive troubleshooting guide for common issues encountered when developing or deploying farruh-folio-wave. List frequent problems such as dependency installation failures, Vite dev server not starting, TypeScript compilation errors, and broken styles after build. Provide step-by-step solutions including clearing node_modules and reinstalling packages, checking Node.js version compatibility, validating TypeScript configurations, and inspecting Vite logs. Address browser-specific rendering issues, particularly around CSS transforms and animations. Cover deployment-related errors like missing _headers file on Netlify or incorrect base href in index.html. Include debugging tips using browser developer tools, console logging, and source maps. Recommend diagnostic commands like `npm audit`, `tsc --noEmit`, and `vite preview`. For each issue, specify relevant files involved (package.json, tsconfig.json, etc.) and preventive best practices. Make content accessible to beginners while offering deep technical insights for advanced users.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Farruh Folio Wave

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
Farruh Folio Wave is a modern, interactive personal portfolio website built with React and TypeScript. The application showcases an individual's professional background including education, experience, skills, projects, and strengths through a visually engaging interface enhanced with animations and dynamic effects.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Present comprehensive professional information in an aesthetically pleasing manner
- Implement smooth navigation with scroll-spy functionality
- Deliver responsive design across device sizes
- Incorporate visual effects (parallax, floating elements, animated particles) to enhance user engagement
- Maintain clean separation between content and presentation via JSON data files

### Target Audience
The primary audience includes potential employers, recruiters, collaborators, and clients who want to learn about the individual's professional capabilities, technical skills, and project experience. Secondary audiences include developers interested in modern frontend techniques and design patterns.

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The application follows a component-based architecture using React with clear separation of concerns:
- **Layout Components**: Navigation system with desktop/mobile responsiveness
- **Page Components**: Individual sections for different aspects of the portfolio
- **UI Components**: Reusable UI elements from shadcn/ui library
- **Effect Components**: Visual enhancements like parallax backgrounds and animated particles
- **Data Components**: Services for loading JSON content

### Design Patterns
The project implements several key design patterns:
- **Component Composition**: Complex views are built by composing smaller, reusable components
- **Separation of Data and Presentation**: Content is stored in JSON files while components handle rendering
- **Custom Hooks**: Reusable logic encapsulated in hooks like `useParallax` and `use-toast`
- **CSS-in-JS with Tailwind**: Utility-first styling combined with CSS Modules for component-specific styles

### System Relationships and Data Flow
```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client Browser] --> B[Index.html]
    B --> C[main.tsx]
    C --> D[App.tsx]
    D --> E[BrowserRouter]
    E --> F[Index.tsx]
    F --> G[Navigation]
    F --> H[ParallaxBackground]
    H --> I[AnimatedParticles]
    H --> J[FloatingWords]
    F --> K[Hero]
    F --> L[About]
    F --> M[Experience]
    F --> N[Projects]
    F --> O[Skills]
    F --> P[Strengths]
    F --> Q[Education]
    F --> R[Contact]
    K --> S[/data/hero.json]
    L --> T[/data/about.json]
    R --> U[/data/contact.json]
    M --> V[/data/experience.json]
    N --> W[/data/projects.json]
    O --> X[/data/skills.json]
    P --> Y[/data/strengths.json]
    Q --> Z[/data/education.json]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `/src/main.tsx`: Application bootstrap and root rendering
- `/src/App.tsx`: Root component with routing and global providers
- `/src/pages/Index.tsx`: Main page composition and layout orchestration

Sources:
- [main.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/main.tsx)
- [App.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/App.tsx)
- [Index.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/pages/Index.tsx)

### Core Modules
- **Navigation Module**: Handles scroll-spy, smooth scrolling, and mobile menu toggle
- **Parallax Effects**: Implements depth-based movement effects based on mouse position
- **Data Loading**: Fetches JSON content for various sections dynamically
- **Form Management**: Contact form state management and submission handling

Sources:
- [Navigation.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/components/layout/Navigation.tsx)
- [ParallaxBackground.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/components/effects/ParallaxBackground.tsx)
- [About.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/components/pages/About.tsx)
- [Contact.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/components/pages/Contact.tsx)

### Configuration Approach
The project uses modern tooling configurations:
- **Vite**: Fast development server and build tool
- **Tailwind CSS**: Utility-first styling with custom theme configuration
- **TypeScript**: Type safety across the codebase
- **ESLint**: Code quality enforcement

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Vite Config] --> B[Development Server]
    A --> C[Production Build]
    D[Tailwind Config] --> E[Design Tokens]
    D --> F[Animation Definitions]
    G[TSConfig] --> H[Path Aliasing @/*]
    G --> I[Compiler Options]
```

Sources:
- [vite.config.ts](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/vite.config.ts)
- [tailwind.config.ts](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/tailwind.config.ts)
- [tsconfig.json](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/tsconfig.json)

### External Dependencies
Key dependencies include:
- **React & React DOM**: Core UI library
- **React Router DOM**: Client-side routing
- **Tailwind CSS & related utilities**: Styling infrastructure
- **shadcn/ui components**: Pre-built accessible UI components
- **@tanstack/react-query**: Data fetching and caching
- **lucide-react**: Icon library
- **zod**: Schema validation

Sources:
- [package.json](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/package.json)

### Integration Points
- **JSON Data Files**: Public data directory serves static content
- **Browser APIs**: Uses fetch API for data loading, localStorage via next-themes
- **Third-party Libraries**: Integrates multiple Radix UI primitives through shadcn

Sources:
- [public/data](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/public/data)

### Component Relationship Diagram
```mermaid
graph TD
    App[App Component] --> Router[BrowserRouter]
    Router --> Routes[Routes]
    Routes --> Index[Index Page]
    Index --> Nav[Navigation]
    Index --> Parallax[ParallaxBackground]
    Parallax --> Particles[AnimatedParticles]
    Parallax --> Floating[FloatingWords]
    Parallax --> Content[Content Sections]
    Content --> Hero[Hero Section]
    Content --> About[About Section]
    Content --> Experience[Experience Section]
    Content --> Projects[Projects Section]
    Content --> Skills[Skills Section]
    Content --> Strengths[Strengths Section]
    Content --> Education[Education Section]
    Content --> Contact[Contact Section]
    Hero --> Data[/data/hero.json]
    About --> Data[/data/about.json]
    Contact --> Data[/data/contact.json]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
The portfolio features a single-page application with:
- Fixed navigation with scroll-spy highlighting
- Parallax background effects that respond to mouse movement
- Floating text elements for visual interest
- Animated particle systems
- Responsive design with mobile menu
- Contact form with configurable display options
- Modular content structure using JSON data files

### Implementation Highlights
- **Dynamic Data Loading**: Each section fetches its content from JSON files
- **Scroll-Spy Navigation**: Automatically highlights current section based on scroll position
- **Mobile-First Design**: Responsive layout with hamburger menu on small screens
- **Visual Effects**: Multiple layers of animation and interaction effects
- **Theme Variables**: CSS custom properties for consistent theming

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> InitialLoad
    InitialLoad --> DataFetching: Load JSON
    DataFetching --> Rendering: Success
    DataFetching --> ErrorState: Failure
    Rendering --> Idle: Ready
    Idle --> Scrolling: User scrolls
    Scrolling --> SectionChange: Cross threshold
    SectionChange --> UpdateNavigation: Highlight active
    Idle --> ClickNavigation: User clicks
    ClickNavigation --> SmoothScroll: Animate to section
    SmoothScroll --> UpdateURL: Update hash
    UpdateURL --> UpdateNavigation: Highlight active
```

Sources:
- [Index.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/pages/Index.tsx)
- [Navigation.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/components/layout/Navigation.tsx)
- [About.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/components/pages/About.tsx#L147-L188)
- [Contact.tsx](/Users/fusioncode/PycharmProjects/sandbox/farruh-folio-wave/src/components/pages/Contact.tsx#L60-L95)
</blog>
